p.s: With this speech delivered at COP26, Attenborough aims not only to force the political leaders into action, but also to give the broader publicum hope for a future worth living.
He is doing this by the use of personal pronouns as well as the use of a choice of rather optimistic words.
Attenborough starts off by addressing the political leaders directly (l. 1).
With the use of the personal pronoun you (l. 1), he makes them responsible for the outcome of COP26 and future, connected with the outcome of the summit.
This gets visible within the next lines where he underlines the fact that their decisions effectaffect our relationship with our world (ll. 5-6).
The repitition of our (l. 5, l. 5, l. 6) stengthenstenghthens the fact that we are all in this together.
On the other hand, however, he states that it is at first their responsibility.
Stressing this starting thesis, he points out that we, meaning all humans, owe the earth.
The earth enabled living (see ll. 10-12) but the humans now destroy the earth (see ll. 13-14).
With this contrast he underlines the paradoxical situation.
He emphasizes that we are all responsible for the climate crisis, due to our culmutative actions, with the use of the personal pronoun our (l. 14).
In addition he enumerates our actions that caused the climate to change: burningof fossil fuels (l. 15), destruction of nature (l. 15), and releasing carbon into the air (see l. 16).
After this enumeration he makes use of short sentences We are already in trouble (l. 17) and The stability we all depend on is breaking (l. 17).
With this he stresses that we are already in trouble and that there is no certain future.
In addition he clarifies the urgency to counter act and to stop this change of an unimaginable speed, symbolized with the short syntax.
Furthermore, Attenborough points out that climate change is already grive reality for a lot of people around the globe.
Underlying this fact he quotes speakers on his screen, which also shows impressive cinematic pictures of nature.
Those humans express their fear regarding the climate change, my world is melting (l. 21) and being terrified to bring a child to this world (see l. 23).
With this stylistic device he makes the climate change real for the political leaders, he creates an emotional atmosphere as well as vivid images in the minds of the political leaders.
Quoting people who express their fear serves to stress the responsibility of the political leaders to counteract climate change.
In addition, Attenborough wantwants to morally appeal to their conscience.
This gets visible as he asks the provokant question: Is this how our story is due to end? (l. 24).
Attenborough himself find an answer to this question, the need to rewrite our history (l. 24).
He wants to turn this tragedy into a triumph (l. 28).
The alliteration of t is used to make his central thesis memorable for the audience.
At the same time he states that there is hope to create a future worth living by rewriting the story and by making the ending better.
However, no one can do this on his own.
Attenborough clearly formulates the goal of working together.
He underlines the statement with the use of an inclusive language (see ll. 29-31).

He invoes himself and every other human, it gets visible that that this speech not only serves to highlight the responsibility of the governments, but that this speech is also there to bring the message of hope across, to the broader public.
There is a shift of responsibility.
At first he only addresses the political leaders (see l. 1) now it gets clear that everyone has to work together with the motivation of hope (ll. 40-41).
He tries to emphasize his optimism with the use of a rather optimistic choice of words, triumph (l. 28), benefits (l. 34), hope (l. 41, l. 53), powerful (l. 51), wonderful recovery (l. 53).
His optimism towards a future worth living if everyone works together is also visible while quoting the speakers.
In contrast to the first speakers, the second ones are far more confident.
This fits to the developing of the speech.
At first Attenborough points out that the climate change is the biggest problem for the generation and that you can feel the effects everywhere.
Towards the end of the speech he claims that there is hope.
This hub is also visible quoting the speakers (see ll. 42-46).
Framing the article he asks the exestentialexistential question did that number starts to drop (ll. 48-49) he says that the answer can be yes (l. 50)
He clarifies that our generation can live in a world of wonderful recovery (l. 52) in contrast to his generation witnessing a terrible decline (l. 51-52).
At the end he uses the personal pronoun you and only addresses the leaders to emphasize that our future is at first in their hands and that the world is looking (l. 54).
All in all it can be said that Attenborough puts a lot of hope into the COP26.
